Himmelsbach | Mahmoud steps up for Cards

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 6:07 a.m. EST December 3, 2014

Louisville freshman Anas Mahmoud llooks over the defense during the second half of an NCAA college basketball scrimmage Sunday, Oct. 19, 2014, in Louisville, Ky. (AP Photo/Timothy D. Easley)(Photo: Timothy D. Easley)

CONNECT 7 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Louisville center Anas Mahmoud had yet to have an impact this season, and that included games against some very bad teams. So there was little reason to expect the rail-thin freshman from Egypt to carve out a role against No. 14 Ohio State on Tuesday night, the Cardinals' biggest game of the year.

And yet with 30.2 seconds left U of L's 64-55 win, there was Mahmoud, stepping to the free-throw line to try to put the game away. Yes, you read that sentence correctly.

"It was kind of funny," Mahmoud said, "but when I was at the line, I wasn't thinking about anything. Just that I'll make it."

Mahmoud's first attempt thudded against the back of the rim and fell through the net. Montrezl Harrell slapped his hand and then slapped his butt. Then the second free-throw missed, but Harrell corralled the rebound, and Mahmoud was the first one there to congratulate him and to thank him.

Mahmoud entered this game with two points, two blocks and three rebounds all season. On this night, he had three points, seven rebounds and two blocks in 24 minutes.

"It's a big game, and Coach P gave me his trust and gave me an opportunity to prove myself a little bit more," Mahmoud said, "and I like it."

Louisville freshman Anas Mahmoud on his big minutes vs. Ohio State

And U of L absolutely needed his help. Starting center Chinanu Onuaku picked up two first-half fouls, and then backup center Mangok Mathiang picked up two first-half fouls. And Matz Stockman injured his neck during pregame warmups and was not available.

So Rick Pitino had little choice but to give Mahmoud a chance. While he did not dominate and he did not star, he did play an important role in an important spot. He did it with the lights on and the national television cameras rolling and the sellout crowd buzzing.

"The first two minutes I came off the bench, I just wanted to do something to help the team and keep their work before the same," Mahmoud said. "That was the hardest part. But once I got it going and started to play and get rebounds and get blocks, I started to go."

Yes, Mahmoud missed both of his field goal attempts, and when the Buckeyes had the ball, they understandably went right at him. But he did not buckle.

With 10 minutes, 21 seconds left in the second half, he brought the crowd to its feet by aggressively swatting the shot of Louisville native D'Angelo Russell out of bounds. A minute later, he calmly drained a pair of free throws.

MORE: U of L holds off Ohio State for marquee victory

MORE: Instant Analysis | Louisville-Ohio State

He had two excellent putback opportunities in the first half, but both shots caromed off the rim. With time, those chances will turn into conversions. Mahmoud, in a sense, symbolizes what this team will be this year. The role players still need to learn, still need to grow.

Yes, there is an excellent corps of upperclassmen, but beyond that, the bench is thin and inexperienced. This is not the deep team of veterans and stars that Cardinals fans have become accustomed to watching.

MORE: What we learned in U of L/Ohio State

MORE: Russell, Snider reconnect at U of L-Ohio State

U of L does not have four senior contributors like last season's team did. As Mahmoud showed, this will be a learning process, but there is clearly potential there.

The fact that Mahmoud was on the court in crunch time speaks volumes about the growing trust Pitino has developed in the inexperienced freshman. And a game like this should do nothing but help his confidence moving forward.

Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach
